total_biomarker_note: Total of 2 biomarkers are Needs Focus in a list of 42 biomarkers.

biomarkers.name: Alanine Aminotransferase
biomarkers.more_info: Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver, with small amounts in the heart and muscles. ALT is a key marker for liver damage, as it is released into the bloodstream when liver cells are injured, such as during hepatitis. Minor increases in ALT may also occur after intense physical activity, alcohol use, or when taking medications like statins used for lowering cholesterol.

biomarkers.name: Albumin
biomarkers.more_info: Albumin is the most abundant protein in the blood, responsible for maintaining osmotic pressure (keeping fluid within blood vessels), transporting certain hormones, and neutralizing free radicals. It is produced by the liver, and low levels can signal liver dysfunction or disease. As people age, albumin levels naturally decline, even without disease. An elevated albumin level typically indicates dehydration, but in healthy individuals, higher levels often reflect good health.

biomarkers.name: Alkaline Phosphatase
biomarkers.more_info: Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) is an enzyme that removes phosphate groups from molecules, most effectively in an alkaline environment. It is found in several tissues, with high concentrations in the liver, bile ducts, and bones. Elevated ALP levels often signal liver or bile duct issues, such as a blockage. Healing bone fractures can also cause a temporary increase in ALP. Low ALP levels may be associated with hypothyroidism, but typically, minor reductions have little clinical significance.

biomarkers.name: Aspartate Aminotransferase
biomarkers.more_info: Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) is another enzyme involved in transferring amino groups, similar to ALT, but primarily found in the liver and heart muscles. AST levels are used to detect liver and heart muscle damage. The ratio of AST to ALT can help differentiate between different causes of liver damage. For example, an AST/ALT ratio less than 1 often suggests acute liver disease or fatty liver, while a ratio greater than 2 may indicate chronic liver disease, such as Wilson’s disease or alcoholic liver disease.

biomarkers.name: Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase
biomarkers.more_info: Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT) is an enzyme found in the liver, prostate, kidneys, and pancreas that plays a role in the transfer of glutamyl groups to molecules. Elevated GGT levels can indicate liver dysfunction, particularly bile duct blockage. It is often the first enzyme to rise when liver function is impaired. GGT can also be elevated in conditions like acute pancreatitis, myocardial infarction, and from certain medications that damage the liver, such as those used in diabetes management.

biomarkers.name: Globulin
biomarkers.more_info: Globulin refers to a group of proteins in the blood that are not albumin. This includes antibodies (gamma globulins) produced by B-cells, as well as proteins like transferrin and ferritin. Elevated gamma globulin levels can be indicative of certain conditions like lymphoma, multiple myeloma, or monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, which are associated with abnormal antibody production.

biomarkers.name: Protein
biomarkers.more_info: The total protein measurement includes both albumin and globulin levels in the blood. It provides an overall picture of protein levels, which are important for various bodily functions, including immune response and nutrient transport.

biomarkers.name: Aortic Pulse Pressure
biomarkers.more_info: Aortic Pulse Pressure (APP) is the difference between the aortic systolic blood pressure (ASBP) and the aortic diastolic blood pressure. It is a useful marker for assessing cardiovascular risk, particularly in individuals over 40 with elevated ASBP or APP. Lifestyle changes or medications may be recommended if APP exceeds certain thresholds, as prolonged high APP can increase the risk of heart disease and stroke. Unlike peripheral SBP, APP better reflects central blood pressure dynamics.

biomarkers.name: Aortic Systolic Blood Pressure
biomarkers.more_info: Aortic Systolic Blood Pressure (ASBP) refers to the peak blood pressure in the aorta during heart contraction (systole). ASBP is a more accurate predictor of cardiovascular disease than peripheral systolic blood pressure (SBP), providing better insight into the risk of heart disease and stroke.

biomarkers.name: Diastolic Blood Pressure (at rest)
biomarkers.more_info: Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP) measures the pressure in the arteries during the relaxation phase of the heart cycle. While DBP increases until middle adulthood and then declines, an increase in SBP with a decrease in DBP in older adults can elevate the risk for cardiovascular diseases. Proper management of both SBP and DBP is essential for cardiovascular health.

biomarkers.name: Resting Heart Rate
biomarkers.more_info: Resting Heart Rate (RHR) is the number of heartbeats per minute when the body is at rest. It is a simple yet effective marker for cardiovascular risk, with lower RHR often correlating with better cardiovascular health. Elevated RHR is linked to increased mortality, particularly from cardiovascular causes, in the absence of other factors that may explain low heart rate.

biomarkers.name: Systolic Blood Pressure (at rest)
biomarkers.more_info: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) is the pressure exerted on artery walls when the heart contracts. High SBP is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events like stroke and heart attack. SBP rises with age, but its predictive value for cardiovascular risk is enhanced when combined with other markers like Augmentation Pressure (AP).

biomarkers.name: HDL Cholesterol
biomarkers.more_info: High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) Cholesterol, often referred to as 'good cholesterol,' helps remove excess cholesterol from tissues, transporting it to the liver for excretion. Higher HDL levels are associated with a lower risk of heart disease and stroke. A healthy diet and exercise can improve HDL function and increase its levels.

biomarkers.name: LDL Cholesterol
biomarkers.more_info: Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol, known as 'bad cholesterol,' can contribute to the buildup of plaque in the arteries, leading to atherosclerosis and increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease. Lowering LDL levels is a primary target for preventing heart disease, with levels below 130 mg/dL considered optimal for most people.

biomarkers.name: Total Cholesterol
biomarkers.more_info: Total Cholesterol is a composite measurement of low-density lipoprotein (LDL), high-density lipoprotein (HDL), and triglycerides (TG). A level below 200 mg/dL is considered healthy, but the individual components of total cholesterol are more important for assessing cardiovascular risk. For instance, a higher HDL-to-LDL ratio may reduce cardiovascular risk even if total cholesterol is elevated.

biomarkers.name: Triglycerides
biomarkers.more_info: Triglycerides are a type of fat found in the blood, produced from excess dietary calories. Elevated triglyceride levels (above 150 mg/dL) are linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and may also be a sign of metabolic dysfunction, such as insulin resistance. Triglyceride levels are most accurately measured after fasting for 8-12 hours.

biomarkers.name: Left Distal CCA Mean CIMT
biomarkers.more_info: The Left Distal Common Carotid Artery (CCA) Mean Carotid Intima-Media Thickness (CIMT) is the average thickness of the inner layers of the left carotid artery. CIMT is a marker of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease risk, with thicker arterial walls indicating a higher risk of cardiovascular events. This measurement helps assess the extent of plaque buildup in the arteries.

biomarkers.name: Right Distal CCA Mean CIMT
biomarkers.more_info: The Right Distal Common Carotid Artery (CCA) Mean Carotid Intima-Media Thickness (CIMT) measures the thickness of the arterial wall in the right carotid artery. CIMT is used to evaluate cardiovascular disease risk, with increased thickness suggesting the presence of atherosclerosis or other vascular issues.

biomarkers.name: Calcium
biomarkers.more_info: Calcium is vital for muscle, nerve, and heart function, with its levels tightly regulated by the kidneys and endocrine system. Abnormal levels—either high (hypercalcemia) or low (hypocalcemia)—can indicate underlying health issues, including parathyroid disorders or kidney disease.

biomarkers.name: Carbon Dioxide
biomarkers.more_info: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is involved in the body's acid-base balance as bicarbonate (HCO3). It helps buffer blood acidity. Low bicarbonate levels may indicate acidosis, often associated with conditions like diabetes, kidney disease, or chronic diarrhea. High bicarbonate suggests alkalosis, which can occur in conditions like vomiting or lung disease.

biomarkers.name: Phosphorus
biomarkers.more_info: Phosphorus is essential for energy production, bone health, and cell function. It is mainly stored in bones and muscles, with small amounts circulating in the blood. Imbalances in phosphorus levels can indicate problems with the parathyroid, kidney function, or vitamin D levels, often affecting calcium metabolism.

biomarkers.name: Potassium
biomarkers.more_info: Potassium is the main intracellular cation, crucial for heart and muscle function. High potassium levels (hyperkalemia) are typically seen in kidney disease or the use of certain medications, and can lead to life-threatening heart arrhythmias. Low potassium (hypokalemia) can cause muscle weakness, cramps, and irregular heart rhythms.

biomarkers.name: Sodium
biomarkers.more_info: Sodium is the primary positively charged ion in the extracellular space, essential for fluid balance, nerve function, and muscle contraction. Imbalances in sodium levels—either high (hypernatremia) or low (hyponatremia)—can result in serious conditions, including dehydration, kidney dysfunction, and heart failure.

biomarkers.name: Iron
biomarkers.more_info: Iron is an essential nutrient involved in red blood cell production and numerous enzyme reactions. While iron deficiency can lead to anemia and fatigue, excessive iron can lead to harmful oxidative stress, increasing the risk for cardiovascular disease and certain cancers. Maintaining an optimal iron balance is crucial for health.

biomarkers.name: Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
biomarkers.more_info: TIBC measures the total amount of iron-binding proteins (transferrin) in the blood. High TIBC is often seen in iron deficiency, while low TIBC suggests iron overload conditions.

biomarkers.name: Unsaturated Iron Binding Capacity (UIBC)
biomarkers.more_info: UIBC is calculated by subtracting serum iron levels from TIBC. It can provide further insight into iron deficiency or overload when used alongside other tests.

biomarkers.name: Vitamin D
biomarkers.more_info: Vitamin D is synthesized by the body when exposed to sunlight, playing a crucial role in calcium metabolism, bone health, and immune function. A deficiency in vitamin D is linked to conditions such as osteoporosis, hypertension, and cardiovascular issues. Vitamin D deficiency can be particularly common in individuals with limited sun exposure or poor dietary intake.

biomarkers.name: Creatinine
biomarkers.more_info: Creatinine is a byproduct of muscle metabolism, and its levels are used to assess kidney function. Since creatinine is filtered by the kidneys, its serum concentration provides insight into how well the kidneys are removing waste. Elevated levels may indicate impaired kidney function, while lower levels can be seen in individuals with reduced muscle mass.

biomarkers.name: Urea Nitrogen in Blood
biomarkers.more_info: Urea Nitrogen in Blood (BUN) is a waste product produced when the liver breaks down proteins. Elevated BUN levels can indicate kidney dysfunction, dehydration, or other conditions affecting kidney health. Normal levels suggest proper kidney filtration, while extremely low levels are rare and not usually of concern unless accompanied by other abnormal findings.

biomarkers.name: Uric Acid
biomarkers.more_info: Uric acid is a byproduct of purine metabolism, which comes from the breakdown of nucleic acids (DNA and RNA). High levels of uric acid can result from excessive production, such as during chemotherapy or radiation, or from decreased excretion due to kidney dysfunction. Conditions like gout and kidney stones are associated with elevated uric acid, as crystals can form in joints or the kidneys. On the other hand, uric acid also acts as an antioxidant, and individuals with high-normal levels may experience better protection against free-radical damage.

biomarkers.name: Free T3
biomarkers.more_info: Free T3 represents the unbound portion of triiodothyronine (T3) that is available for cellular uptake. Lower levels of free T3 are associated with decreased metabolic function, which can lead to symptoms like fatigue, weight gain, and depression. Free T3 tends to decline with age, contributing to various age-related health issues.

biomarkers.name: Thyroid Stimulating Hormone
biomarkers.more_info: Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is produced by the pituitary gland and stimulates the thyroid to release thyroid hormones (T3 and T4). High TSH levels suggest that the body is not producing enough thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism), while low TSH levels indicate excessive thyroid hormone production (hyperthyroidism).

biomarkers.name: Thyroxine
biomarkers.more_info: Thyroxine (T4) is the precursor to the more active thyroid hormone triiodothyronine (T3). Most of the thyroid hormone in circulation is in the form of T4, which is converted into T3 in the liver and other tissues. T4 levels help assess thyroid function and are useful in diagnosing thyroid disorders.

biomarkers.name: Glucose
biomarkers.more_info: Glucose is a simple sugar that serves as the body's primary energy source. It is critical for cellular function and is absorbed from food, primarily carbohydrates. Abnormal glucose levels, either too high or too low, can indicate issues such as diabetes or hypoglycemia, respectively.

biomarkers.name: Insulin
biomarkers.more_info: Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that regulates blood glucose levels. It facilitates the uptake of glucose into cells for energy or storage. Elevated fasting insulin levels may indicate insulin resistance, a precursor to type 2 diabetes, while normal insulin levels suggest good metabolic health.

biomarkers.name: Hemoglobin
biomarkers.more_info: Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells responsible for transporting oxygen. When glucose binds to hemoglobin, it forms glycated hemoglobin (Hemoglobin A1C). The percentage of glycated hemoglobin reflects average blood glucose over a 3-4 month period, helping assess diabetes management and blood sugar control.

biomarkers.name: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)
biomarkers.more_info: MCH measures the average amount of hemoglobin in each red blood cell. This value helps diagnose different types of anemia. Low MCH is often seen in iron deficiency anemia.

biomarkers.name: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC)
biomarkers.more_info: MCHC calculates the concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells, indicating the amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell. It is particularly useful in diagnosing iron deficiency anemia, with low values signaling a lack of sufficient hemoglobin.

biomarkers.name: Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)
biomarkers.more_info: MCV measures the average size of red blood cells. Variations in MCV can indicate disease states or nutrient deficiencies. Larger red blood cells are commonly seen in vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, while smaller cells are often associated with iron deficiency anemia.

biomarkers.name: Mean Platelet Volume (MPV)
biomarkers.more_info: MPV measures the average size of platelets. High MPV values indicate larger platelets, which may increase the risk of heart attacks or strokes, while lower MPV values suggest smaller platelets, which can lead to bleeding disorders.

biomarkers.name: Platelets
biomarkers.more_info: Platelets are critical components in blood clotting, produced from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow. They also release growth factors that support tissue repair. Abnormal platelet counts—either too low (thrombocytopenia) or too high (thrombocytosis)—can lead to increased bleeding or clotting risks. A normal platelet count ranges between 150,000 and 450,000 per microliter.

biomarkers.name: Red Blood Cells
biomarkers.more_info: Hemoglobin A1C, or glycated hemoglobin, is a form of hemoglobin that attaches to glucose in the blood over time. The percentage of glycated hemoglobin in red blood cells reflects average blood glucose levels over the past 3-4 months. Elevated levels suggest poor blood sugar control, indicating diabetes or prediabetes, while lower levels reflect healthier glucose regulation. Glycated hemoglobin is part of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs), which can impair protein function, leading to tissue damage and aging.
